output.conclusion: This course provides a comprehensive understanding of power systems, equipping you with the knowledge to analyze, design, and operate modern power grids effectively.
output.introduction: Welcome to Power Systems Engineering! This course delves into the core principles and practical applications of electrical power systems, covering generation, transmission, distribution, and protection. Designed for intermediate learners, this course builds upon fundamental electrical engineering concepts.

chapters.description: Overview of power system components, structure, and operation.  Introduction to single-line diagrams and per-unit system.
Modeling of generators, transformers, and transmission lines for power flow studies.
Introduction to power flow equations and iterative solution methods (Gauss-Seidel, Newton-Raphson).
Calculation of fault currents and voltages during balanced three-phase faults.
Analysis of single-line-to-ground, line-to-line, and double-line-to-ground faults using symmetrical components.
Overview of protective relaying schemes and their application in power systems.
Introduction to steady-state, transient, and dynamic stability.
Application of the equal area criterion for assessing transient stability.
Understanding voltage collapse phenomena and methods for voltage stability improvement.
Automatic Generation Control (AGC) and its role in frequency regulation.
Optimal allocation of generation resources to minimize operating costs.
Introduction to smart grid concepts, including advanced metering infrastructure (AMI) and demand response.
